title-group.article-title: New routes to flame retard polyamide 6,6 for electrical applications

article-meta.aff: 1Unité des Matériaux et Transformations (UMET), équipe Ingénierie des Systèmes Polymères, CNRS-UMR 8207, ENSCL, Université Lille Nord de France, Villeneuve d’Ascq cedex, France
2Rhodia Research and Development Center, 69192 Saint Fons, France

author-notes.corresp: Maude Jimenez, Unité des Matériaux et Transformations, équipe Ingénierie des Systèmes Polymères, CNRS-UMR 8207, ENSCL, Université Lille Nord de France, 59652 Villeneuve d’Ascq cedex, France. Email: maude.jimenez@univ-lille1.fr

abstract.p: Polyamide 6,6 is used in many industrial fields such as housing materials, transport or electrical engineering applications. Due to its chemical composition, this polymer is easily flammable. As far as the main applications concern electrical and electronic equipments, its flame-retardant properties become an important requirement. The most discriminating tests are the limiting oxygen index, UL94 and glow wire flammability index. The aim is to obtain high limiting oxygen index values, V0 rating at UL94 test for 1.6- or 0.8-mm-thick samples and a validation at 960°C of the glow wire flammability index. The usual way to fire retard polyamide 6,6 consists of incorporating an important loading of fire-retardant additives, which often reduce the intrinsic properties of the polymer. It is also difficult to combine a thin polymer thickness (e.g. 0.8 mm) and a high amount of additives because of processing issues. In this article, we first carried out a rapid screening to determine the best fire retardant for polyamide 6,6 and its optimized amount to achieve the previously defined fire retardant properties. It was shown that an amount of 23% of aluminium diethylphosphinate Exolit OP1230 allows reaching the requirements. Then, carrying out two different surface treatments (coating of polysiloxanes by plasma-enhanced chemical vapour deposition and use of an intumescent waterborne varnish), we have tried to reach the same results. It was shown that the use of surface treatment alone does not allow reaching the objectives. As a consequence, the combination of the bulk approach at low loadings with the surface treatment was investigated. This new route allows the combination of the condensed phase mechanism of the intumescent barrier with the gas phase mechanism of the OP1230 and leads to very good results: the use of 5% of the flame-retardant additives combined with a 100-µm-thick waterborne intumescent varnish leads to better results than a 23% of additive loading.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polyamide 6,6 (PA6,6) is used in many industrial fields such as housing materials, transport or electrical engineering applications (connectors, circuit breakers, electric distribution and industrial controls). Due to its chemical composition, this polymer is easily flammable. As far as the main applications concern electrical and electronic equipments (EEEs), its flame-retardant properties become an important requirement, and the materials have to comply with severe fire-retardant test methods. The most discriminating tests are the limiting oxygen index (LOI), UL94 and glow wire flammability index (GWFI). The aim is to obtain the highest LOI values, V0 rating at UL94 test for 1.6- or 0.8-mm-thick samples and a validation at 960°C for GWFI test.

To reduce the fire hazards of polymeric materials, several ways can be considered: the most common one consists of incorporating flame-retardant additives into the polymer.1 This technique is quite simple and cheap, and numerous flame retardants are commercially available. However, this approach leads to some processability issues and to the decrease of the intrinsic properties of the polymer since the loading is usually rather high (typically more than 15 wt.%). Moreover, some of the commonly used additives (in particular some halogen-based compounds) can have ecological drawbacks.2–4

The chemical modification of the macromolecule is another method.5 This technique is not easy to conduct on an industrial scale with most thermoplastic polymers, and can be rather expensive and so is not commonly used.

Surface modification (physical6 or chemical7 treatments) seems to be an attractive alternative method as it would allow concentrating the fire retardant properties onto the polymer surface (where the flammability occurs) and would thus allow preserving the bulk properties of the material. In a previous study carried out in the laboratory, a new route to improve fire retardant properties of a polymer by deposing a thin film on its surface using plasma-assisted polymerization technique has been investigated.8–12 The plasma-enhanced chemical vapour deposition (PECVD) is one of the most widely used process for the deposition of thin films. The plasma-assisted polymerization of organosilicon compounds is an interesting technique to create thin polysiloxane-based films on the surface of various substrates even if the literature data about this process are rather sparse. Polysiloxane-based films are known to show good thermal stability, interesting flame properties and an interesting hydrophobicity.13

In this article, two approaches are used and then combined in order to improve the flame-retardant properties of PA6,6. First, flame-retardant additives are added to the matrix, and the influence of the additives content on the flame-retardant properties is investigated. Second, two different surface treatments are investigated. The cold plasma polymerization of organosilicon films has first been used to coat PA6,6. Films are obtained from the polymerization of 1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane (TMDSO) monomer doped with oxygen under nitrogen microwave post-discharge low-pressure cold plasma.11 The second way consists of applying an intumescent waterborne transparent varnish on the PA6,6. An intumescent coating is a coating that ‘when heated above its critical temperature, begins to melt, to bubble and to swell, forming a thick, non flammable multi cellular insulative barrier which affords protection for substrate’. Intumescent varnishes are generally developed for wood and metals as they usually show poor adhesion to polymers. However, as detailed in precedent articles,14,15 an adequate treatment of the polymer surface allows improving the adhesion between the coating and the polymeric substrate, and thus allows keeping the properties of the intumescent coating during a fire.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PA6,6 has been supplied by Rhodia Engineering Plastics. Polymer plates (100 × 100 × 3 mm3, 130 × 10 × 1.6 mm3 and 60 × 60 × 1 mm3) have been prepared by Rhodia Engineering Plastics using an injection press DEMAG (injection pressure between 500 and 700 bars, and mould temperature between 70°C and 90°C). Some samples (PA6,6 glass fibre (GF)) have been prepared with 25% of boron-free GFs (Advantex 983; Owens Corning Corporation) via melt compounding using a twin-screw corotating extruder ZSK40 (rotating speed of 250 r/min and injection flow rate of 35 kg/h). Different fire-retardant additives have been incorporated using the same melt compounding process: aluminium diethylphosphinate (Exolit OP1230; Clariant), melamine polyphosphate (Melapur 200; BASF), melamine pyrophosphate (Budit 311; Budenheim), melamine cyanurate (Budit 314; Budenheim) and Exolit OP1312 (Clariant; mixture of OP1230, Melapur 200 and zinc borate (FB500; US Borax)).

TMDSO (97%) provided by Aldrich Chemicals was used for the plasma treatment. The intumescent varnish was ‘Pyroplast HW100’ supplied by Rütger Organics. It is a varnish of confidential composition; however, we analysed its chemical composition using an electron probe microscopy analysis (EPMA) on a CAMECA SX100 at 20 kV and 20 nA. We showed (Figure 1) that this varnish is mainly composed of carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus and silica with traces of iron, aluminium and magnesium. It is thus halogen, boron and heavy metal free.

caption.p: EPMA analysis of Pyroplast HW100 waterborne intumescent varnish.
EPMA: electron probe microscopy analysis.

sec.title: Surface treatment: PECVD
sec.p: The experimental setup used to make the polysiloxane-based deposit is shown in Figure 2. A nitrogen flow (purity: 99.995%, supplied by Air Liquide) is excited by a microwave discharge produced in a quartz tube. By continuous pumping, excited and long-life species are led to the reactor chamber where the cold remote nitrogen plasma appears like a yellow afterglow. The cold remote nitrogen plasma is free of charged particles (substrate damages are avoided), and the temperature is approximately ambient.

caption.p: Experimental setup of PECVD.
PECVD: plasma-enhanced chemical vapour deposition; TMDSO: 1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane.

sec.p: The monomer (TMDSO), premixed with oxygen (purity ≥ 99.5%, supplied by Air Liquide), is injected into the cold remote nitrogen plasma through a coaxial injector. The deposition process is carried out in two steps: first the samples are treated by the cold remote nitrogen plasma in order to increase the adhesion quality of the organosilicon film on the polymer. Then, the deposition step is performed without air re-exposure. The polymerization process leads to a previously studied white glow.16,17 Samples are successively coated on each face with an open-air exposure between the two steps.
Different treatment conditions leading to different coating thicknesses have been compared (Table 1).

caption.p: Experimental conditions of PECVD

fn.p: PECVD: plasma-enhanced chemical vapour deposition; TMDSO: 1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane.

sec.title: Surface treatment: intumescent coating
sec.p: The waterborne transparent intumescent varnish has been applied on the polymer plates after a flame treatment (IPROS flame apparatus). It is possible to modify the number of treatments, the treatment speed and the distance between the substrate and the flame on this apparatus. The optimized conditions are presented in Table 2.

caption.p: Optimized flame treatment conditions

sec.p: The coating has been sprayed during 10 s using a semi-industrial spraying machine (CLID apparatus).

sec.title: Characterization of the deposit
sec.p: The thickness of the coating has been evaluated by surface profilometry using an Alpha-step IQ surface profiler. The Alpha-step IQ is a mechanical, stylus-based step profiler that can measure step heights from some micrometers up to 2 mm, save programmes for later use and provide data analysis and image capture of scans.

The adherence of the film on the substrate has been evaluated according to the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D3359-B standard using an Elcometer 107 Cross Hatch Cutter.18 Digital images of this experiment have been observed using an optical microscope, the Olympus GX 51. The best ranking is 5B, the worst is 0B.

The contact angle measurements have been carried out using a GBX Digidrop goniometer. The contact angles are measured from the profile of liquid drops of distilled water placed on the polymer at controlled temperature (25°C). It is a quantitative measurement of the wetting of a solid by a liquid. These measurements allow evaluating the hydrophilic or hydrophobic character of the surface.

High-resolution solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were acquired on a Bruker Avance II 400 spectrometer (static field 9.4 T) operating at a Larmor frequency of 79.22 MHz for 29Si. The ground samples were packed in 4-mm fused zirconia rotors and sealed with Kel-F caps. The spectra were recorded at 10 kHz spinning rate at the magic angle (magic angle spinning (MAS)) with proton cross-polarization (CP) and a delay of 900 s between the two pulses.

sec.title: Fire tests
sec.p: The LOI tests have been performed using a Stanton Redcroft instrument according to the ASTM D 2863/77 standard.19 This test allows the determination of the minimal oxygen rate, in an oxygen–nitrogen mixture, ensuring the combustion of a sample held vertically (130 × 10 × 1.6 mm3 or 130 × 10 × 0.8 mm3).

The cone calorimeter measurements were carried out using a Stanton Redcroft Cone Calorimeter according to the ASTM E 1354-90a standard.20 The samples (standard size: 100 × 100 × 3 mm3) were exposed under a 35 kW/m2 external heat flux, which represents the heat flux found in the vicinity of solid-fuel ignition source. Conventional data such as rate of heat release (RHR) and ignition time (IT) can then be obtained.

The GWFI test has been carried out on sheets (60 × 60 × 1 mm3) according to the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) 60695-2 standard.21 The glow wire is heated via an electrical resistance. A test specimen is held for 30 s against the tip of the glow wire with a force of 1 N. The product is characterized by the highest temperature (for a test specimen), at which one of the following conditions are fulfilled: flames or glowing of the test specimen extinguishes within 30 s after removal of the glow wire, and there is no ignition of the wrapping tissue placed underneath the test specimen or there is no ignition of the test specimen at all. The GWFI test is used to simulate the effect of heat that might arise in malfunctioning electrical equipment. The test results provide a way to compare the ability of materials to extinguish flames and their ability not to produce particles capable of spreading fire.

The vertical burning test was conducted using a vertical burning tester on bars (130 × 10 × 1.6 mm3 or 130 × 10 × 0.8 mm3) according to UL94 test ASTM D3801-1996 standard.22 The best ranking for this 1996 standard version is V0 when burning time is short (<10 s) and when there is no dripping of flaming particles, whereas the worst rating corresponds to ‘not classified’ (NC) when the sample burns for more than 30 s or up to the holding clamp at 130 mm from the ignition point.

sec.title: Bulk treatment
sec.p: First, the use of flame-retardant additives to improve the behaviour of PA6,6 was investigated. The study was carried out on pure PA6,6 and on PA6,6 filled with 25% of GF (PA6,6 GF), which are known to reinforce its mechanical properties.23 Different flame retardants reported to be efficient in polyamides, such as aluminium diethylphosphinate (Exolit OP1230), melamine polyphosphate (Melapur 200), melamine pyrophosphate (Budit 311), melamine cyanurate (Budit 314) and Exolit OP1312 (mixture of OP1230, MP 200 and zinc borate FB500), have been incorporated in the virgin and glass-reinforced matrices at 23 wt.%. The aim was to reach the highest LOI value, to obtain a V0 rating at 0.8 and 1.6 mm and to validate the GWFI test at 960°C.

The results obtained for the material containing 23 wt.% of additives are compared in Tables 3 and 4, respectively, for the virgin and glass-reinforced PA6,6. Most of the samples show a V0 rating for both 1.6 and 0.8 mm (except the formulation with MP 200 and Budit 314) and allow validating the GWFI at 960°C.

caption.p: Fire performance for PA6,6 formulations containing 23% of fire retardants

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; LOI: limiting oxygen index; GWFI: glow wire flammability index; NC: not classified.

caption.p: Fire performance for PA6,6 GF formulations containing 23% of fire retardants

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; GF: glass fibre; LOI: limiting oxygen index; GWFI: glow wire flammability index; NC: not classified.

sec.p: The best results in terms of LOI with and without GFs correspond to the incorporation of 23% of aluminium diethylphosphinate (OP1230). The mechanism of action of OP1230 in PA6,6 has been elucidated by Braun et al.24 Their conclusion is that the mechanism of action of OP1230 in PA6,6 is mostly a gas phase mechanism with flame inhibition by the release of phosphorus-containing radicals. The authors explain that this flame inhibition effect corresponds to the superior LOI performance of the formulation PA6,6/GF/OP1230.

The additive Budit 314 also shows interesting results when the PA6,6 does not contain GF, but the LOI decreases drastically (from 40% to 25%), and the sample is NC when GFs are incorporated. The reason for the interference by glass reinforcement in the action of melamine cyanurate has not been completely elucidated. However, it could be suspected that the GFs retard melt flow that is responsible for the good fire retardant properties of PA6,6, since heat is ‘evacuated’ by dripping. Moreover, the fibres could act as a ‘wick’ and should favour heat transfer to the polymer.25,26

The influence of the content of OP1230 on fire retardant properties of PA6,6 GF is then investigated. The GWFI, LOI, UL94, time to ignition (TTI) and peak rate of heat release (pRHR) with the different percentages of OP1230 incorporated in PA6,6 GF are presented in Table 5.

caption.p: Fire test results for different percentages of OP1230 in PA6,6 GF

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; GF: glass fibre; LOI: limiting oxygen index; GWFI: glow wire flammability index; TTI: time to ignition; pRHR: peak of rate of heat release; NC: not classified.

sec.p: It can be observed that the incorporation of only 8% of OP1230 allows obtaining good fire properties. Indeed, even if V0 rating at UL94 is not achieved, the sample, which is NC at 5%, shows a V1 rating for 8% of additives (extinction time superior to 10 s and dripping of polymer). Moreover, it validates the GWFI at 960°C (Figure 3) and decreases the pRHR of around 50%. The V0 rating is only obtained when 23% of the additives are added, which is an important amount that might modify the intrinsic properties of the polymer such as its mechanical properties. The IT decreases to about 30 s when OP1230 is incorporated; however, the RHR max reaches 147 kW/m2 for a 23% of loading against 515 kW/m2 for pure PA6,6 GF.

caption.p: GWFI tests at 960°C for 1-mm-thick sample (PA6,6 GF 8% OP1230).
GWFI: glow wire flammability index.

sec.p: We have seen that the GWFI test is validated for 8% of OP1230, but 23% is needed to obtain the highest LOI values as well as lower pRHR and V0 rating. This is why the idea to develop a surface treatment allowing to put only few amounts of additives or to suppress them has been developed.

Some of our precedent articles showed that a polysiloxane deposit on different textiles26 as well as on polyamide 6 nanocomposites11 allows improving the fire resistance of the substrates. It was thus decided first to see the effect of such a polysiloxane layer on the PA6,6.

sec.title: Surface characterization of treated PA6,6
sec.p: The influence of different parameters (O2, N2 and TMDSO flow rates, distance injector/substrate, power, time of pre-treatment and treatment) on the thickness of the polysiloxane deposit was first investigated. The different conditions (Table 4) lead to four different coating thicknesses: 1.2, 2.6, 6.8 and 11.7 µm.
Table 6 reports the surface characterization results in terms of wettability, thickness and adherence of the deposit compared to the reference (pure PA6,6).

caption.p: Surface characterization test results (thickness, contact angle and adherence)

sec.p: Looking at the water contact angle, surface becomes more hydrophobic than the untreated PA6,6. According to the tests, contact angles remain constant whatever the thickness of the coating, meaning that the chemical species formed on the surface are similar and that the deposit is homogeneous.
The nature of the deposits has been studied using 29Si solid-state NMR, similar to the study previously reported.27 The structure assignments are detailed in Table 7.

caption.p: 29Si NMR peak assignments

sec.p: The TMDSO-based film contains M1, D2, T2, T3, Q3 and Q4 groups. The peak at −11 ppm (M1) reflects the precursor structure (TMDSO), showing that the polymerization is incomplete in that there are Si–H end groups.

Figure 4 illustrates the adhesion of the organosilicon film observed after tape test (ASTM D3359-B) obtained by optical microscopy. The thicker the film, worse is the adhesion. This is attributed to the fact that when the thickness of the coating increases, the deposit tends to delaminate.

caption.p: Illustration of adhesion of coating by optical microscopy.

sec.title: Flame-retardant properties of the coated PA6,6
sec.p: Flame-retardant performances of the films deposited on PA6,6 have been evaluated using LOI, GWFI, UL94 and cone calorimeter measurements. All samples are NC at UL94 test, and none of them validate the GWFI test. However, even if the GWFI test of treated PA6,6 is not validated, it has to be noted that a thin protective silicon barrier is formed during the first seconds of the test, but once this layer cracks, the sample burns completely as it does not contain a fireproofing agent in its formulation to stop the flame spreading.

Table 8 shows the LOI values for samples of PA6,6 (thickness of 1.6 mm). The LOI value of the coated PA6,6 is improved: it increases as soon as the film thickness reaches 1.2 µm. A maximum value of 36% is obtained for a film thickness of 6.8 µm. Then, it decreases to 34% for a film thickness of 11.7 µm. This might be due to the poor adhesion of the coated layer for this thickness (Figure 4). Therefore, the coating allows improving the fire retardant properties of the PA6,6 according to this test.

caption.p: LOI values versus the thickness of the film deposited on PA6,6

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; LOI: limiting oxygen index.

sec.p: Figure 5 shows test specimen at LOI and LOI + 1 as a function of the coating’s thickness, compared to virgin PA6,6. In the value of oxygen concentration corresponding to the LOI, the combustion stops quicker after inflammation, and the sample burns only on a height of less than 1 cm. When the oxygen concentration corresponds to LOI + 1, the material degrades faster, producing a large amount of carbonaceous residue, which shows weak mechanical resistance. However, the behaviour of the treated PA6,6 sharply differs from the one of virgin PA6,6. A thin protective silicon crust is formed on the surface of the PA6,6 when the material is treated, which prevents the flowing of the sample. This might explain the increase of LOI as soon as 1.2 µm of deposit is done.

caption.p: Illustration of LOI for treated PA6,6.
LOI: limiting oxygen index; PA6,6: polyamide 6,6.

sec.p: The curves showing evolution of the RHR of PA6,6 treated by PECVD are compared to the behaviour of untreated PA6,6 in Figure 6.

caption.p: RHR values versus time for virgin and treated PA6,6.
RHR: rate of heat release; PA6,6: polyamide 6,6.

sec.p: RHR curves corresponding to the untreated PA6,6 can be described as follows. Towards 75 s, the material degrades enough to release flammable gases in a sufficient amount so that their mixture with air is ignited by the electric arc of the electrode in the cone calorimeter. The combustion begins with the liberation of a strong calorific flow (RHR increases rapidly). Towards 110 s, slowing down of the liberation of heat occurs and then a new peak is observed with a maximum towards 150 s corresponding to the thermal return of the back face. Beyond this time, the majority of the polymer was consumed, and then fuel gases rarefy until exhaustion of the whole polymer.

The treated samples ignite approximately at the same time than the untreated PA6,6. Further to this ignition, a thin white film is formed at the surface of the material. This structure is not particularly effective because it does not cause reduction of the RHR in regard to the untreated polymer. However, the curve profile is not exactly the same as that of the PA6,6 profile: the plasma coating shows a small protective effect after ignition (appearance of a peak between 100 and 150 s), which disappears when the thin layer cracks.

In conclusion, it has been demonstrated that a thin layer of polysiloxane coating shows some effectiveness in the first minutes of fire, but it is too thin to have a long-time effect. This is why we developed an approach by combining a little amount of the fire-retardant additive (OP1230 in our case) and polysiloxane coating.

sec.title: Combination between fire retardant additive and PECVD treatment
sec.p: The fire retardant properties of PA6,6 GF including OP1230 treated with the organosilicon film are compared with those of PA6,6 GF treated with the organosilicon film in Table 9. It is observed that the combined approach (the use of a fire-retardant additive at low loading and the surface treatment) allows providing optimal fire performances. The PA6,6 containing GFs and 8% of GF OP1230 coated with a film with thickness of 11.7 µm leads to a V0 classification at the UL94 test. Moreover, it has to be noted that all samples pass the GWFI test at 960°C.

caption.p: UL94 classification versus the thickness of the film deposited on PA6,6 GF and PA6,6 GF 8% OP1230

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; GF; glass fibre; NC: not classified.

sec.p: Looking at Table 9, it can be noticed that the best fire-retardant behaviour (V0 rating) is obtained for PA6,6 containing 8% GF OP1230 coated with a film with thickness of 11.7 µm. During the test, the structure of the polymer leads to the formation of a protective layer, which is reinforced by the polysiloxane coating.

The coating of a thin film (11.7 µm) of polysiloxanes on a PA6,6 fire retardant with a low amount of OP1230 (8%) shows an improvement of the classification at UL94 test. In theory, this experiment gives interesting results when the coating is thick enough. Even if the low-pressure cold plasma technique seems not really adapted for big panels, it could, however, be interesting for industries to apply it on small pieces, as this technique is well adapted for small dimensions. However, we did not test the application of such process on three-dimensional complex shape panels, and we, thus, cannot extrapolate if the coating will cover the whole sample homogeneously. This is why we decided to test another type of surface treatment: the use of a thin waterborne transparent intumescent varnish applied on the polyamide substrate.

sec.title: Surface treatment: waterborne intumescent varnish
sec.p: Intumescent coatings and varnishes have had a large increase in use as a method of passive fire protection over the past few years. Their main purpose is to protect construction materials such as steel and wood in case of fire. Intumescent coatings provide passive fire protection and resist fire and avoid its passage and/or that of gaseous products of combustion. When heated above a critical temperature, the intumescent coating swells and forms an expanded charred layer acting as a physical barrier, which slows down heat and mass transfers between gas and condensed phase.

Intumescent coatings are very rarely applied on polymers, usually because of their bad adhesion. In previous articles,14,15 we showed that by making a preliminary flame treatment on polypropylene, polypropylene composites and polycarbonate, a good adhesion of waterborne intumescent coatings and varnishes could be achieved, thus allowing the intumescent coating to protect efficiently the polymeric substrates in case of a fire. In fact, passing a flame very rapidly onto a surface allows cleaning it from organic residues, oxidizing it (creation of hydroxyl or carboxylic functions) and improving its wettability, thus enabling a good contact between the coating and the surface. Moreover, it does not degrade the polymer surface, and no change of colour or charring is observed.

In this study, we decided to work with a transparent waterborne intumescent varnish usually applied on wood. We did not add any primer or topcoat but first carried out a flame treatment on the polymer surface (PA6,6 GF).

sec.title: Surface characterization of coated PA6,6
sec.p: The adhesion test on a 100-µm-thick coating shows that the flame treatment allows improving the adhesion from 3B ranking for the PA6,6 GF that has not been exposed to flaming to 5B ranking for the materials pre-treated with flame treatment (Figure 7). Thus, this flame treatment will be further used in this study.

caption.p: (a) 3B ranking for non-flame-treated samples compared to (b) 5B for flame-treated samples.

sec.title: Flame-retardant performances of coated PA6,6
sec.p: The flame-retardant performances of the PA6,6 GF coated with the intumescent varnish have been evaluated according to LOI, UL94 and GWFI (Table 10).

caption.p: Flame-retardant performances of PA6,6 GF coated with 100 µm of varnish

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; GF; glass fibre; LOI: limiting oxygen index; GWFI: glow wire flammability index.

sec.p: The 100-µm-thick intumescent varnish is very efficient both on 0.8- and 1.6-mm-thick PA6,6 plates: the LOI values reach 52–54 vol.% for coated PA6,6 GF compared to 21 vol.% for pure PA6,6 GF. All samples reach the V0 ranking for UL94 test. However, one of our main criteria is also to pass the GWFI test at the maximum temperature, that is, 960°C. With a 100-µm-thick coating, we only reach 750°C, which is not sufficient for use as EEE. If we apply a 200-µm-thick coating, the GWFI test at 960°C is validated. However, since materials are 0.8 mm thick, the coating, applied on both sides, represents an excessively large increase (+50%).

This is why we decided, as previously described in the case of plasma-treated materials, to combine the bulk and surface treatment by incorporating a very low amount of OP1230 in PA6,6 GF and by coating it with the 100-µm-thick coating.

sec.title: Combination between fire-retardant additive and intumescent varnish
sec.p: In that case, the OP1230 content in the PA6,6 GF was fixed at 5 wt.%. Indeed, it was previously reported that for PA6,6 GF 5% OP1230 (Table 3), the material is NC at UL94 and presents a low LOI value (26 vol.%). However, considering the intumescent coating as surface treatment, it was demonstrated that both UL94 and LOI can be sharply improved (V0 rating and LOI higher than 50 vol.%). That is why we have chosen 5% in this case and not 8%.

The flame-retardant properties obtained when 5% of OP1230 added in bulk and the 100 µm of intumescent varnish are combined are presented in Table 11 and compared with the PA6,6 GF + intumescent varnish and PA6,6 GF + 23% OP1230, which is the optimized formulation considering the bulk approach.

caption.p: Flame-retardant performances of PA6,6 GF + 5% of OP1230 + 100 µm intumescent varnish compared to other formulations

fn.p: PA6,6: polyamide 6,6; GF: glass fibre; LOI: limiting oxygen index; GWFI: glow wire flammability index.

sec.p: The addition of 5% of OP1230 to the formulation combined with the 100-µm-thick coating allows increasing the LOI to high values (63–65 vol.%), keeping the V0 ranking for samples of 0.8 and 1.6 mm thickness and validating the GWFI test at 960°C. It has to be highlighted that the results in terms of LOI are even better than those obtained with the formulation loaded with 23% of OP1230.

Figure 8 compares RHR curves obtained during cone calorimeter test for the PA6,6 GF; PA6,6 GF containing 5% of OP1230; PA6,6 GF covered with 100 µm intumescent varnish; PA6,6 GF with a combination of 5% of OP1230 and 100 µm intumescent varnish and PA6,6 GF loaded with 23% of OP1230.

caption.p: RHR values versus time for the formulations combining the bulk approach and the use of an intumescent varnish.
RHR: rate of heat release; GF: glass fibre; PA6,6: polyamide 6,6.

sec.p: The 100-µm-thick intumescent coating allows reducing the RHR drastically. pRHR decreased by around 60% compared to the non-coated PA6,6 GF 5% OP1230 and by around 80% compared to the PA6,6 GF. The RHR of coated with PA6,6 GF 5% OP1230 shows a maximum value of around 100 kW/m2 after 600 s, whereas the formulation PA6,6 GF 23% OP1230 shows a maximum value of 147 kW/m2 after 200 s. The IT also increases: ignition begins at around 220 s for coated samples versus 54 s for non-coated materials loaded with 5% OP1230 and begins at 69 s for PA6,6 GF with 23% of OP1230. Only little differences are observed with and without OP1230 when the coating is applied: in terms of cone calorimetry, the results are even better without any bulk treatment.

As a conclusion, the best formulation to be used as EEEs could be defined as a combination of 5% of OP1230 and 100-µm-thick intumescent varnish. For this formulation, the LOI is the highest (63%–65%), the sample is V0 rated at both 0.8 and 1.6 mm, the GWFI test is validated at 960°C and the sample shows excellent results during cone calorimeter test. The interest of this new approach is to combine two different mechanisms of action: a condensed phase mechanism through the formation of an intumescent barrier and the gas phase action of OP1230, which releases phosphorus-based radicals. We could have thought that the OP1230 action would be inhibited by the presence of the intumescent coating; however, it seems to play a complementary effect, particularly for LOI and GWFI test. It seems that when the intumescent barrier is crossed, the OP1230 takes over from it and releases the species allowing protecting the polymer at 960°C. A complementary study on the mechanisms involved will be published in another article.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, we aimed at developing new routes to fire retard PA6,6 for application as EEEs by combining two approaches : the incorporation of little amount of fire retardants in the bulk (in order to avoid the modification of the intrinsic properties of the polymer as much as possible) and a surface treatment.

The objective was to meet the severe criteria of EEE, that is, highest LOI values, a V0 ranking at UL94 test on 0.8- and 1.6-mm-thick samples and validation of the GWFI test at 960°C. We first showed that these properties are obtained by adding 23% of aluminium diethylphosphinate (OP1230) in the bulk, and our aim is to reduce this amount. Two different surface treatments were applied: a polysiloxane coating deposited using PECVD and a waterborne transparent intumescent varnish deposited by spraying.

Combining a 11.7-µm-thick polysiloxane coating with 8% of OP1230 added in the bulk allows validating the V0 ranking and the GWFI test at 960°C. However, in that case, the LOI is relatively low (34 vol.%). This is the reason why a second route was investigated, consisting of applying an intumescent varnish on the material. A 100-µm-thick coating is not sufficient enough to validate the GWFI test at 960°C on virgin PA6,6 GF, even if V0 ranking, high LOI values and excellent cone calorimeter test results are obtained. However, the incorporation of 5% of OP1230 in bulk, combined with the use of 100 µm intumescent coating, allows achieving the best performances: very high LOI values (63%–65%), V0 ranking on 0.8- and 1.6-mm-thick samples and GWFI test validated at 960°C. Moreover, this solution gives even better performances in terms of LOI values, IT and RHR than a 23% of OP1230–containing material.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Maude Jimenez is Assistant Professor in Lille University. Her research interests include the comprehension of the mechanism of intumescence and the development of surface treatments by physical methods such as low pressure and atmospheric cold plasma. Her area of interest has further broadened to include the weathering of intumescent coatings.
Hélène Gallou is a young doctor who worked on this subject as PhD student with the financial support of Rhodia.

Sophie Duquesne is professor in the “Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Lille” Her research interests include the processing of new flame retardant coatings and the comprehension of the mechanism of intumescence from both chemical and physical aspects. Her area of interest has further broadened to include the recyclability of fire-retarded polymers andz materials.

Charafeddine Jama is professor in the “Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Lille”. His research is devoted to the development of new processes for surface treatment and modification using cold plasma technologies. His area of interest has further broadened to include corrosion studies.

Serge Bourbigot is Professor in the “Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Lille”. His research interests include the development of new flame retardant formulations for polymeric materials and textiles, the simulation of heat transfer in intumescent coatings, and NMR methods for characterizing (nano)filled polymers and chars.
Xavier Couillens and Franco Speroni are members of a Rhodia Research and Development center based in Saint-Fons, France. They work in the Product Development team on polyamide based products.
